previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: sunspot data constituted several dates assumed contemporaneous single event. dates need calibration unit year 2016.

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates
what: Simple model for combining Gaussian dates
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: Let’s first use simple Bayesian model. output function combination_Gauss() Markov chain posterior distribution Bayesian model.
code: data(sunspot)  MCMC1 <- combination_Gauss(   M = sunspot$Age[1:5],   s = sunspot$Error[1:5],   refYear = rep(2016, 5),   studyPeriodMin = 900,   studyPeriodMax = 1500,   variable.names = c('theta') )

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates > Simple model for combining Gaussian dates
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: First, let’s check convergence Markov chain parameter. plot chunk unnamed-chunk-2 Gelman diagnotic gives point estimates 1, convergence reached.
code: plot(MCMC1) gelman.diag(MCMC1) #> Potential scale reduction factors: #>  #>       Point est. Upper C.I. #> theta          1          1

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates > Simple model for combining Gaussian dates
what: Statistics of the posterior distribution of the event.
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: Now, can use package ArchaeoPhases order describe posterior distribution parameters. focus posterior distribution date interest, .e. parameter theta. plot chunk unnamed-chunk-3 date (mean posterior distribution) sunspot estimated using simple Bayesian model combines dates, dates 1028 years Christ. date associated 95% confidence interval : [1025, 1032].
code: MCMCSample1 <- cbind(MCMC1[[1]], MCMC1[[2]]) MCMCEvent1 <- as_events(MCMCSample1, calendar = CE()) plot(MCMCEvent1[, 1], level = 0.95) (M1 <- summary(MCMCEvent1[, 1], level = 0.95)) #>        mad mean sd  min   q1 median   q3  max start  end #> theta 1028 1028  3 1022 1027   1028 1029 1034  1025 1032

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates
what: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates and handling potential outliers
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: Let’s use function combinationWithOutliers_Gauss(). plot chunk unnamed-chunk-4 output function combinationWithOutliers_Gauss() Markov chain posterior distribution Bayesian model. focus posterior distribution date interest .e. parameter ’theta*. plot chunk unnamed-chunk-5 date (mean posterior distribution) sunspot, estimated using simple Bayesian model combines dates allows outliers, dates 1028 years Christ. date associated 95% confidence interval : [1025, 1032].
code: MCMC2 <- combinationWithOutliers_Gauss(   M = sunspot$Age[1:5],   s = sunspot$Error[1:5],   refYear = rep(2016, 5),   outliersIndivVariance = rep(1, 5),   outliersBernouilliProba = rep(0.2, 5),   studyPeriodMin = 800,   studyPeriodMax = 1500,   variable.names = c('theta') ) plot(MCMC2) MCMCSample2 <- cbind(MCMC2[[1]], MCMC2[[2]]) MCMCEvent2 <- as_events(MCMCSample2, calendar = CE()) plot(MCMCEvent2[, 1], level = 0.95) (M2 <- summary(MCMCEvent2[, 1], level = 0.95)) #>        mad mean sd  min   q1 median   q3  max start  end #> theta 1028 1028  3 1021 1027   1028 1029 1035  1025 1032

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates
what: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates with a random effect
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: Let’s now use function combinationWithRandomEffect_Gauss(). plot chunk unnamed-chunk-6 output function combinationWithRandomEffect_Gauss() Markov chain posterior distribution Bayesian model. focus posterior distribution date interest .e. parameter ’theta*. plot chunk unnamed-chunk-7 date (mean posterior distribution) sunspot, estimated using simple Bayesian model combines dates allows random effects, dates 1027 years Christ. date associated 95% confidence interval : [1018, 1033].
code: MCMC3 <- combinationWithRandomEffect_Gauss(   M = sunspot$Age[1:5],   s = sunspot$Error[1:5],   refYear = rep(2016, 5),   studyPeriodMin = 0,   studyPeriodMax = 1500,   variable.names = c('theta') ) plot(MCMC3) MCMCSample3 <- cbind(MCMC3[[1]], MCMC3[[2]]) MCMCEvent3 <- as_events(MCMCSample3, calendar = CE()) plot(MCMCEvent3[, 1], level = 0.95) (M3 <- summary(MCMCEvent3[, 1], level = 0.95)) #>        mad mean sd min   q1 median   q3  max start  end #> theta 1027 1027  5 994 1025   1027 1029 1042  1018 1033

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates
what: Event Model : Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates with individual random effects
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: want date event, can use Event model combining Gaussian dates. example, investigate posterior distribution date event (called ’theta*) posterior distribution dates associated event.

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates > Event Model : Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates with individual random effects
what: Generating the Markov chain of the posterior distribution
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: Finally, let’s use function eventModel_Gauss() first 10 dates dataset sunspot. study period given calendar year (BC/AD). output eventModel_Gauss() Markov chain posterior distribution.
code: MCMC4 <- eventModel_Gauss(   M = sunspot$Age[1:5],   s = sunspot$Error[1:5],   refYear = rep(2016, 5),   studyPeriodMin = 900,   studyPeriodMax = 1500,   variable.names = c('theta', 'mu') )

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates > Event Model : Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates with individual random effects
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: First, let’s check convergence Markov chain parameter. plot chunk unnamed-chunk-9 plot chunk unnamed-chunk-9 Gelman diagnotic gives point estimates 1, convergence reached.
code: plot(MCMC4) gelman.diag(MCMC4) #> Potential scale reduction factors: #>  #>       Point est. Upper C.I. #> mu[1]          1          1 #> mu[2]          1          1 #> mu[3]          1          1 #> mu[4]          1          1 #> mu[5]          1          1 #> theta          1          1 #>  #> Multivariate psrf #>  #> 1

previous_headings: Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates > Event Model : Bayesian model for combining Gaussian dates with individual random effects
what: Statistics of the posterior distribution of the event.
title: Introduction to ArchaeoChron
text: focus posterior distribution event interest (parameter ’theta*). plot chunk unnamed-chunk-10 date (mean posterior distribution) sunspot, estimated using simple Bayesian model combines dates allows individual random effects, dates 1026 years Christ. date associated 95% confidence interval : [1018, 1034].
code: MCMCSample4 <- cbind(MCMC4[[1]], MCMC4[[2]]) MCMCEvent4 <- as_events(MCMCSample4, calendar = CE()) plot(MCMCEvent4[, 6], level = 0.95) (M4 <- summary(MCMCEvent4[, 6], level = 0.95)) #>        mad mean sd  min   q1 median   q3  max start  end #> theta 1027 1026  5 1007 1024   1027 1029 1042  1018 1034

title: Bayesian Modeling of Archaeological Chronologies
text: ArchaeoChron provides list functions Bayesian modeling archaeological chronologies. Bayesian models implemented ‘JAGS’ (‘JAGS’ stands Just Another Gibbs Sampler. program analysis Bayesian hierarchical models using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulation. See http://mcmc-jags.sourceforge.net/ “JAGS Version 4.3.0 user manual”, Martin Plummer (2017) https://sourceforge.net/projects/mcmc-jags/files/Manuals/.). inputs measurements associated standard deviations study period. output MCMC sample posterior distribution event date without radiocarbon calibration. first time using ArchaeoChron, take moment read vignette wrote estimation combination dates (mainly Gaussian). questions, feel free contact us (anne.philippe@univ-nantes.fr).
code: To cite ArchaeoChron in publications use:    Philippe A, Vibet M (2023). _ArchaeoChron: Bayesian Modeling of   Archaeological Chronologies_. Université de Nantes, Nantes, France. R   package version 0.2, <https://ArchaeoStat.github.io/ArchaeoChron/>.  Une entrée BibTeX pour les utilisateurs LaTeX est    @Manual{,     author = {Anne Philippe and Marie-Anne Vibet},     title = {{{ArchaeoChron: Bayesian Modeling of Archaeological Chronologies}}},     year = {2023},     organization = {Université de Nantes},     address = {Nantes, France},     note = {R package version 0.2},     url = {https://ArchaeoStat.github.io/ArchaeoChron/},   }

title: Bayesian Modeling of Archaeological Chronologies
text: can install released version ArchaeoChron CRAN : development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("ArchaeoChron") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("ArchaeoStat/ArchaeoChron")

title: Bayesian Modeling of Archaeological Chronologies
text: ArchaeoChron provides functions return Markov chain posterior distribution one following Bayesian models: combination_Gauss(): simple combination Gaussian dates. combinationWithOutliers_Gauss(): combine Gaussian dates using outliers model described Bronk Ramsey (2009). combinationWithRandomEffect_Gauss(): combine Gaussian dates random effect (Congdon 2010). eventModel_Gauss(): combine Gaussian dates individual random effect (Lanos Philippe 2017). chrono_Gauss(): simple chronology Gaussian dates. chronoOutliers_Gauss(): chronology Gaussian dates outlier modeling (Bronk Ramsey 2009). chronoEvents_Gauss(): chronology events combining Gaussian dates (Lanos Philippe 2017). eventModel_C14(): combine radiocarbon dates.

what: ArchaeoChron: Bayesian Modeling of Archaeological Chronologies — ArchaeoChron-package
title: ArchaeoChron: Bayesian Modeling of Archaeological Chronologies — ArchaeoChron-package
text: Provides list functions Bayesian modeling archaeological chronologies. Bayesian models implemented 'JAGS' (Plummer 2003). inputs measurements associated standard deviations study period. output MCMC sample posterior distribution event date without radiocarbon calibration.

what: Bayesian Chronologies of Gaussian Dates Using the Event Model — chronoEvents_Gauss
title: Bayesian Chronologies of Gaussian Dates Using the Event Model — chronoEvents_Gauss
text: Bayesian Chronologies Gaussian Dates Using Event Model

title: Bayesian Chronologies of Gaussian Dates Using the Event Model — chronoEvents_Gauss
code: chronoEvents_Gauss(   M,   s,   measurementsPerEvent,   studyPeriodMin,   studyPeriodMax,   refYear = NULL,   numberChains = 2,   numberAdapt = 10000,   numberUpdate = 10000,   variable.names = c("theta"),   numberSample = 50000,   thin = 10 )

title: Bayesian Chronologies of Gaussian Dates Using the Event Model — chronoEvents_Gauss
text: M [`numeric`] vector measurements. s [`numeric`] vector errors. measurementsPerEvent [`numeric`] vector giving number measurements per event. studyPeriodMin length-one [`numeric`] vector specifying start time study period. studyPeriodMax length-one [`numeric`] vector specifying end time study period. refYear [`numeric`] vector specifying reference year. `NULL` (default), AD years expected. numberChains [`integer`] giving number parallel chains model (see [rjags::jags.model()]). numberAdapt [`integer`] giving number iterations adaptation (see [rjags::jags.model()]). numberUpdate [`integer`] giving number iterations update model . variable.names [`character`] vector giving names variables monitored (see [rjags::coda.samples()]). numberSample [`integer`] giving number iterations monitor (see [rjags::coda.samples()]). thin [`integer`] giving thinning interval monitors (see [rjags::coda.samples()]).

title: Bayesian Chronologies of Gaussian Dates Using the Event Model — chronoEvents_Gauss
text: [`mcmc.list`][coda::mcmc.list()] object.
